Show HN: Lago: Open-source metering and usage-based billing
text:
At Lago, we strongly believe that billing, whether it's subscription-based, usage-based or hybrid, is still a nightmare for engineers. Many of the existing billing engines are home-made, painful to build and maintain. Billing shouldn't require a dedicated team within your companies, or hours per week of maintenance. It should be easy to track, price and experiment usage.

Our vision is to help your company switch to usage-based billing easily.

Our open-source project lets you set up any types of pricing in hours, not months. Lago is particularly useful for hybrid, usage-based or per-seat pricing. It's also incredibly flexible for metering.

- Lago Open-Source: https://github.com/getlago/lago - Lago Cloud: reach out at https://forms.gle/eT7zgqcvq8dgt94g7 - Documentation: docs.getlago.com - Open Roadmap: https://github.com/getlago/lago/projects/2

Your feedback is our fuel, so don't hesitate to try this yourself or reach out

Ask HN: Is the Firebase Auth Secure?
text:
According to the documentation, I can obtain the firebase "API" token via the following javascript (see [01]): FirebaseAuth.instance.currentUser().getIdToken();

It seems like the id token is used as access token/api key?

As there are so many discussions that storing tokens in a palace reachable by JS is very insecure [02]. I'm wondering what I'm missing here.

Also, I do not really understand why is it considered to be so much more insecure? As soon as malicious code has access to the JS, he can as well make the fetch requests from the users browsers, sending along all the required cookies.

So, is it still valid not to use local storage for tokens?

[01] https://firebase.google.com/docs/reference/js/v8/firebase.User#getidtoken

[02] http://cryto.net/~joepie91/blog/2016/06/13/stop-using-jwt-for-sessions/
